;;菲律宾马尼拉的太阳能灯艺术装置点亮，纪念台风海燕发生 10 周年。这场台风是世界上有记录以来最强的热带气旋之一，在菲律宾中部登陆，造成数千人死亡。
;

;;超级台风海燕;将在菲律宾举行祈祷和点燃蜡烛，以纪念这场导致 7,000 多人死亡或失踪的风暴十周年。

;

;海燕是有记录以来最强的风暴之一，风力高达每小时 315 公里（195 英里）。它掀起了海啸般的波浪，摧毁了这个群岛国家的中部岛屿。

;

;莱特省首府塔克洛班，;首当其冲的是风暴的狂怒;，五米高的风暴潮几乎完全摧毁了该市，袭击了大部分贫困的沿海社区。< /p>;

;

;;相关：;;随着台风的破坏性变得越来越大，菲律宾人计算气候危机的成本;

;
;

;Roselyn Salazar Torres 这么说回忆起 2013 年 11 月 8 日的情景，她感到“痛苦”，当时洪水冲走了她家的小屋，她和两个小孩挣扎着漂浮在水面上，避免被碎片击中。

;

;“我没有希望我和我的家人能够幸存于尤兰达”，托雷斯告诉法新社，他用的是菲律宾的风暴名称。

; ;

;“当时我和两个孩子一起被海浪翻腾。我真的以为我的整个家庭都会在这场悲剧中被消灭。”

;

;风暴袭来时，托雷斯和她的丈夫正在外出工作，现在他们和四个孩子住在一间 12 平方米的房子里。 129 平方英尺）的混凝土房屋，位于为幸存者建造的几个庞大的搬迁地点之一。

;

;“明天我们将一如既往地为失去的朋友和亲人点燃蜡烛。然后我们就为自己准备一顿小宴席。”托雷斯说道。

;

;“我很庆幸我们在超强台风中幸存下来，并在10年后还活着。”

;

;< a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/jun/30/a-year-of-marcos-jr-how-a-dictators-son-has-changed-the-philippines">;总统费迪南德·马科斯;将参加在塔克洛班海滨会议中心举行的弥撒和纪念活动，当海燕袭击该国时，许多人一直在该中心避难。

;

;马科斯还将参加在该市举行的备灾会议。

; ;

;晚上，塔克洛班居民计划放置沿着城市的街道点燃蜡烛，哀悼在灾难中丧生的朋友和家人。

;

;63 岁的伊曼纽尔·科比拉 (Emmanuel Corbilla) 是在风暴中没有失去任何家人的幸运者之一。但作为村长，科尔比拉鼓励他的选民参加一场纪念死去邻居的弥撒，并为他们点燃蜡烛。

;

;“我们点燃蜡烛来表达我们对受害者的爱，并且也是为了感谢上帝给了我们第二次生命。”他说。

;

;大约 6,300 人在台风中丧生，十年后仍有一千多人失踪。

; Wed, 08 Nov 2023 11:52:01 +0800 2023 on track to be the hottest year on record, say scientistshttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/nov/08/2023-on-track-to-be-the-hottest-year-on-record-say-scientists
;;2023-11-08T03:00:05Z;
;
;;11 月 3 日，野火向西班牙巴伦西亚东部城镇帕尔马德甘迪亚推进。
;< p>;在本月举行具有里程碑意义的气候峰会之前，科学家们宣布，2023 年世界将比有记录以来的任何一年都更热。

;

;“我们几乎可以肯定地说，2023 年将是最热的一年。”哥白尼气候变化服务中心副主任萨曼莎·伯吉斯 (Samantha Burgess) 表示：“这是有记录以来最热的一年，目前比工业化前平均温度高出 1.43 摄氏度。” “第 28 届缔约方会议采取雄心勃勃的气候行动的紧迫感从未如此强烈。”

;

;哥白尼科学家发现上个月是全球有记录以来最热的 10 月，气温比预期高出 1.7 摄氏度1800 年代末的 10 月平均气温是这样的。

;

;通过燃烧化石燃料和破坏自然，人类将吸热气体排入大气中，自工业革命以来，地球温度已升高 1.2 摄氏度。科学家发现，2023 年 10 月的全球气温异常是其数据集中所有月份中第二高的，仅次于前一个月。

;

;“事实上，我们正在经历这一创纪录的炎热年份，这意味着人类创纪录的气温异常伦敦帝国理工学院的气候科学家弗里德里克·奥托（Friederike Otto）说。 “今年，极端热浪和干旱因极端气温而变得更加严重，导致数千人死亡、人们失去生计、流离失所等。这些都是重要的记录。

;

;“这就是为什么《巴黎协定》是一项人权条约，不遵守其中的目标就是大规模侵犯人权。”

;
;

;;相关：;;“一切都干涸了”：亚马逊陷入困境森林砍伐导致干旱;

;
;

;八年前的巴黎峰会上，世界领导人承诺在本世纪末努力阻止地球升温 1.5 摄氏度。但目前的政策设定为将气温升高约 2.4 摄氏度。

;

;雷丁大学气象研究科学家阿克谢·德奥拉斯 (Akshay Deoras) 表示：“2023 年 10 月的炎热天气是另一个不幸的例子，它表明温度记录是如何变化的。”被巨大的优势粉碎。由于温室气体排放量增加和热带太平洋厄尔尼诺现象导致的全球变暖对地球造成了严重打击。”

;

;上个月创纪录的高温;科学家们惊呆了;。他们预计极端气温是由温室气体污染、厄尔尼诺自然天气模式的回归以及包括硫污染下降和汤加火山喷发在内的其他一些因素共同推动的。

;

;哥白尼表示，厄尔尼诺现象仍在继续发展，但迄今为止的温度异常低于 1997 年和 2015 年之前的强烈事件期间达到的温度。

;

;“令人恐惧的是，全球2023年6月以来的气温比2015年下半年厄尔尼诺现象更强的时候要暖和得多。”Deoras说。 “我们的星球继续经历气象史上不幸的里程碑，在接下来的几个月里看到新记录也就不足为奇了。”

;

;哥白尼发现 2023 年 1 月至 10 月期间的全球平均气温为有记录以来最高。它比 2016 年 10 个月的平均气温（当前最热年份的记录保持者）高出 0.1 摄氏度。

;

;雷丁大学气候科学家理查德·艾伦 (Richard Allan) 表示：“只有快速、大规模减少所有部门的温室气体排放，我们能否避免这些屡屡出现的破纪录的温暖头条新闻，更重要的是，限制伴随着世界迅速变暖而日益严重的潮湿、炎热和干燥的极端情况。”

; Wed, 08 Nov 2023 11:22:01 +0800 ‘Ohio spoke tonight’: voters add abortion rights to state constitutionhttps://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/nov/07/ohio-issue-1-abortion-rights-vote-result

;
;;人们在汉密尔顿酒店的停车场举着标语，敦促对旨在保护俄亥俄州堕胎权的宪法修正案进行投票周四在辛辛那提举行的早期现场投票期间，县选举委员会进行了投票。
;

;俄亥俄州选民投票决定将堕胎权纳入州宪法，这是堕胎权支持者在唯一允许堕胎的州取得的重大胜利今年 11 月的投票。

;
;

;;相关：;;堕胎仍然受到帮助推翻罗伊的黑钱集团的威胁;

;
;

;第一期通过根据公投宣布后不久的结果，超过 57% 的选票。

;

;自去年美国最高法院推翻罗伊诉韦德案，堕胎问题再次被讨论以来，俄亥俄州的堕胎准入问题一直陷入困境。各州和;导致 16 个州禁止;几乎所有堕胎。俄亥俄州有一项为期六周的堕胎禁令，该禁令短暂生效，直到; ;法院暂停。; ; ; ;周二的结果应该会阻止该禁令的实施。周二投票结束后，堕胎权支持者聚集在哥伦布市中心由俄亥俄州生殖权利联盟主办的观察派对上，该联盟支持第一期。每次有机构或新闻机构宣布第一期活动结束后，派对上爆发出欢呼声，当宽屏电视上播放的 CNN 播放了观看派对本身的片段时，欢呼声达到了高潮。

;

;“俄亥俄州今晚发表了讲话，”一位与会者说道。告诉另一个人。 “我们做到了！”

;

;俄亥俄州生殖权利联盟联合主席劳伦·布劳维尔特(Lauren Blauvelt)在结果公布后第一个发表讲话。 “堕胎就是医疗保健，”她在观看派对上说道，赢得了热烈的掌声。

;

;美国人在众多民意调查中对罗伊的推翻表达了愤怒和不同意见，迄今为止，堕胎权利倡导者赢得了每一次与堕胎相关的公投自从罗伊垮台以来，包括堪萨斯州和肯塔基州等可靠的红色州。然而，作为唯一一个在 2023 年进行与堕胎相关的公投的州，俄亥俄州是对这些活动人士维持愤怒并利用其推动法律变革的能力的考验。

;

;外部资金涌入竞选。仅在过去的几个月里，为拥护《第一期》和堕胎权所做的努力就筹集了近 3000 万美元，比反堕胎力量多了大约 2000 万美元。

;

;堕胎反对者用声称《第一期》的广告猛烈抨击俄亥俄州人保护一系列与生殖相关的权利，将使未成年人能够在父母不知情的情况下获得堕胎甚至性别肯定护理。法律专家;告诉《卫报》;，这些说法被夸大了.

;

;由于将堕胎权写入州宪法现在是保护堕胎权的最佳方式，因此与堕胎相关的公投目前正在全国范围内进行，包括亚利桑那州和佛罗里达州等紫色州。十多个州最终可能会在 2024 年就堕胎问题进行投票。

; Wed, 08 Nov 2023 10:22:01 +0800 Singing by boys’ choir ‘sounds more brilliant’ when girls in audiencehttps://www.theguardian.com/science/2023/nov/08/singing-by-boys-choir-sounds-more-brilliant-when-girls-in-audience
;;2023-11-08T00:01:02Z;
;
;;来自德国莱比锡圣托马斯合唱团的年轻歌手
;

;在一首令人振奋的歌曲背后研究表明，全男性合唱团是一种进化力量，它因塑造充满希望的青蛙和蟋蟀的性生活而闻名。

;

;精英男孩的录音 ;合唱团;曾经由约翰·塞巴斯蒂安·巴赫在德国莱比锡指挥，他们透露，合唱团中身体更成熟的男孩提高了他们的声音当女孩在观众席时，会发出诱人的声音。

;

;这种效应仅在 16 至 19 岁的老年低音歌手中出现，被认为与在青蛙和蟋蟀中更常见的合唱行为相当，这会改变他们各自的叫声，以便在吸引异性的合唱中从人群中脱颖而出。

;

;“当女孩在观众席上时，男孩的歌声听起来更明亮，更具吸引力、更响亮，但丹麦奥胡斯大学大脑音乐中心的神经科学教授 Peter Keller 领导了这项工作。

;

;Keller 和他的同事与著名的圣托马斯合唱团合作，在莱比锡合唱团的一名学生和前成员提到，当女性观众在场时，男孩们的歌声似乎以几乎难以察觉的方式发生了变化。

;

;

;但目前尚不清楚，与敏感的声学设备相比，人们是否能够察觉到这种微妙的变化是否可以，是否会因为增强歌手的共振峰而使声音更有吸引力。

;

;“并不是每个听的人都知道”凯勒补充道。

;

;

;个别低音歌手是否在表演中脱颖而出尚不得而知。一种可能性是，声音最低沉的歌手的推动更广泛地引起了人们对低音部分的关注。除了四名男低音外，合唱团还包括四名16至18岁的男高音、四名12至16岁的女高音和四名12至13岁的女高音。

;

;根据科学家的说法，研究结果表明合唱团演唱是一种特殊的形式合作与竞争（后者可能出于性动机）可以同时存在。 “你有一群人在一起工作，”凯勒说，“但同时又各自拥有平行的沟通渠道，发出竞争信号：选我！”

; Wed, 08 Nov 2023 09:22:01 +0800 China releases methane plan as hopes rise for new climate agreement with UShttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/nov/08/china-methane-plan-climate-agreement-us
;;2023-11-08T00:29:00Z;
;
;;德克萨斯州莱诺拉石油和天然气设施中的耀斑燃烧甲烷和其他碳氢化合物
;

;中国发布了期待已久的甲烷减排计划，这表明中国正朝着与美国达成新的气候协议迈进。

;

;北京在 2021 年格拉斯哥第 26 次缔约方大会上首次承诺减少甲烷排放量，作为与美国联合协议的一部分。但两年来，削减计划未能实现。周二，美国和中国的气候特使在加利福尼亚州桑尼兰兹结束了为期四天的会谈，该报告的发布表明两国可能很快在下周的总统会议和联合国气候会议之前就新的气候协议取得突破性进展。 COP28，本月底。

;

;就连解振华和约翰·克里本周的会面地点也被一些人视为吉利。这栋豪华庄园是中国领导人习近平 2013 年与巴拉克·奥巴马 (Barack Obama) 首次会面的地方。

;
;

;;相关：;;尽管有气候目标，中国仍在继续煤炭热潮;

;
;

; Xi and Joe Biden, the US president, are expected to meet at the Apec summit in San Francisco next week, with the Xie-Kerry meeting laying the groundwork for a potential climate agreement.

;

;The Xi-Obama meeting led to a historic US-China ;climate agreement; in 2014, in which China pledged to peak CO2 emissions by 2030 (a target that it is expected to meet ahead of time). That in turn established the foundation for the Paris Agreement the following year, in which 196 countries agreed to limit the increase in the global average temperature to below 2C, compared with pre-industrial levels.

; ;

;Now insiders are cautiously optimistic that a new US-China climate agreement could be on the horizon. It is a “golden opportunity”, said Li Shuo, the incoming director of the China Climate Hub at the Asia Policy Institute, adding that elections in the US and in Taiwan could distract both sides from climate discussions in 2024.

;

;Both the US and China want to show that there are “some guardrails in the US-China relationship, with climate being one of the bright spots,” said Byford Tsang, senior policy adviser at E3G, a climate change thinktank.

;

;At Cop26 in Glasgow, China and the US agreed to establish a working group on climate action. That plan was put on ice after ;Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan;, but recent US-China meetings appear to have put negotiations back on track. When Kerry visited Beijing in July, he described the meetings as “extremely warm and productive”.

;

;Still, there are likely to be major sticking points in reaching any agreement, especially when it comes to specific commitments.

;

;The methane reduction plan, for example, avoids making numerical targets. “China is very cautious in making international pledges,” said Tsang. Beijing “doesn't like when its hands are constrained on the international stage.”

;

;The US, along with over 150 other countries, has committed to cutting methane emissions by 30% by 2030, but China has so far not joined any such pledge. “Methane is not a technical issue, it's a political issue,” said Li, adding that progress on a plan reflected the state of US-China relations.

;

;Another increasingly contentious point, the curbing of fossil fuel emissions, primarily through phasing out coal. China is the world's biggest producer of greenhouse gases, nearly 90% of which comes from the energy sector. Over 60% of power generation comes from coal.

;

;Phasing out coal is an essential part of China's net zero by 2060 goal, but since power cuts and blackouts closed factories across China in 2021, the government has focused on energy security and coal phaseout is increasingly sensitive. Campaigners say the topic has become hard to discuss.

;

;According to experts, China's energy security problems could be solved by improvements to the country's grid and reforms to the domestic energy market, rather than burning more coal.

;

;Local governments in China approved 50.4 GW of new coal power in the first six months of this year, meaning that China is on track to approve a similar amount of coal to 2022, which was a record high since 2015.

;

;That is despite the fact that in ;a speech; in January last year, Xi called on China to gradually “reduce traditional energy sources while promoting reliable substitution of new [renewable] energy sources”, a slight departure from his previous emphasis on building new renewable capacity before dismantling coal infrastructure. But local incentives still support the permitting of new coal power plants, even if they don't contribute to China's energy needs.

;

;Kerry and Xie are publicly at odds on the coal issue, with the US climate envoy calling for the issue to be the focus of COP28 negotiations, while his Chinese counterpart has said that phasing out fossil fuels completely is “unrealistic”. Still, analysts are hopeful there will soon be some kind of agreement, at least in principle, on new climate goals. With a presidential meeting on the horizon, both sides are aware that now may be the only moment in the next 12 months to break new ground.

;A live-action film based on the hit game franchise The Legend of Zelda is in development, gaming giant Nintendo confirmed on Wednesday.

;

; Wed, 08 Nov 2023 07:22:01 +0800 Ex-Meta employee says his warnings of Instagram’s harm to teens were ignoredhttps://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/nov/07/meta-facebook-employee-congress-testimony-instagram-child-harm-social-media
;;2023-11-07T21:10:08Z;
;
;;The Instagram logo is seen on a cell phone in Boston, on 14 October 2022.
;

;On the same day whistleblower Frances Haugen was testifying before Congress about the harms of Facebook and Instagram to children in the fall of 2021, a former engineering director at the social media giant who had rejoined the company as a consultant sent an alarming email to Mark Zuckerberg about the same topic.

;

;Arturo Béjar, known for his expertise on curbing online harassment, recounted to the Meta CEO of his own daughter's troubling experiences with Instagram.但他表示，他的担忧和警告没有得到重视。 And on Tuesday, it was Béjar's turn to testify to Congress.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Meta sued by 33 states over claims youth mental health endangered by Instagram;

;
;

;“I appear before you today as a dad with firsthand experience of a child who received unwanted sexual advances on Instagram,” he told a panel of US senators.

;

;Béjar worked as an engineering director at Facebook from 2009 to 2015, attracting wide attention for his work to combat cyberbullying.他认为事情正在好转。 But between leaving the company and returning in 2019 as a contractor, Béjar's own daughter had started using Instagram.

;

;“She and her friends began having awful experiences, including repeated unwanted sexual advances, harassment,” he testified Tuesday. “She reported these incidents to the company and it did nothing.”

;

;In the 2021 note, as first reported by the Wall Street Journal, Béjar outlined a “critical gap” between how the company approached harm and how the people who use its products – most notably young people – experience it.

;

;“Two weeks ago my daughter, 16, and an experimenting creator on Instagram, made a post about cars, and someone commented 'Get back to the kitchen.'这让她深感不安，”他写道。 “与此同时，该评论远未违反政策，而且我们的阻止或删除工具意味着此人将转到其他个人资料并继续传播厌女症。 I don't think policy/reporting or having more content review are the solutions.”

;

;Béjar testified before a Senate subcommittee on Tuesday about social media and the teen mental health crisis, hoping to shed light on how Meta executives, including Zuckerberg, knew about the harms Instagram was causing but chose not to make meaningful changes to address them.

;

;He believes that Meta needs to change how it polices its platforms, with a focus on addressing harassment, unwanted sexual advances and other bad experiences, even if these problems don't clearly violate existing policies. For instance, sending vulgar sexual messages to children doesn't necessarily break Instagram's rules, but Béjar said teens should have a way to tell the platform they don't want to receive these types of messages.

;

;“I can safely say that Meta's executives knew the harm that teenagers were experiencing, that there were things that they could do that are very doable and that they chose not to do them,” Béjar told the Associated Press (AP). This, he said, makes it clear that “we can't trust them with our children”.

;

;Opening the hearing Tuesday, Connecticut senator Richard Blumenthal, a Democrat who chairs the Senate judiciary's privacy and technology subcommittee, introduced Béjar as an engineer “widely respected and admired in the industry” who was hired specifically to help prevent harms against children, but whose recommendations were ignored.

;

;“What you have brought to this committee today is something every parent needs to hear,” added Missouri senator Josh Hawley, the panel's ranking Republican.

;

;Béjar pointed to user surveys carefully crafted by the company that show, for instance, that 13% of Instagram users – ages 13 to 15 – reported having received unwanted sexual advances on the platform in the previous seven days.

;

;Béjar said he doesn't believe the reforms he's suggesting would significantly affect revenue or profits for Meta and its peers. They are not intended to punish the companies, he said, but to help teenagers.

;

;“You heard the company talk about it: 'Oh this is really complicated,'” Béjar told AP. “不，不是这样。 Just give the teen a chance to say: 'This content is not for me' and then use that information to train all of the other systems and get feedback that makes it better.”

;

;The testimony comes amid a bipartisan push in Congress to adopt regulations aimed at protecting children online.

;

;Meta, in a statement, said: “Every day countless people inside and outside of Meta are working on how to help keep young people safe online.这里提出的有关用户认知调查的问题突出了这一努力的一部分，此类调查促使我们创建了诸如潜在有害内容的匿名通知和评论警告等功能。我们还与家长和专家合作推出了 30 多种工具来支持青少年及其家人获得安全、积极的在线体验。 All of this work continues.”

;

;Regarding unwanted material users see that does not violate Instagram's rules, Meta points to its 2021 “content distribution guidelines” that say “problematic or low-quality” content automatically receives reduced distribution on users' feeds. This includes clickbait, misinformation that's been fact-checked and “borderline” posts, such as a “photo of a person posing in a sexually suggestive manner, speech that includes profanity, borderline hate speech, or gory images”.

;

;In 2022, Meta also introduced “kindness reminders” that tell users to be respectful in their direct messages – but it only applies to users who are sending message requests to a creator, not a regular user.

;

;Today's testimony comes just two weeks after dozens of US states sued Meta for harming young people and contributing to the youth mental health crisis. The lawsuits, filed in state and federal courts, claim that Meta knowingly and deliberately designs features on Instagram and Facebook that addict children to its platforms.

;

;Béjar said it is “absolutely essential” that Congress passes bipartisan legislation “to help ensure that there is transparency about these harms and that teens can get help” with the support of the right experts.

;

;“The most effective way to regulate social media companies is to require them to develop metrics that will allow both the company and outsiders to evaluate and track instances of harm, as experienced by users. This plays to the strengths of what these companies can do, because data for them is everything,” he wrote in his prepared testimony.

; Wed, 08 Nov 2023 05:22:02 +0800 Canada’s emissions cut plan insufficient to meet targets, official report findshttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/nov/07/canada-emissions-cut-plan-insufficient-report

;;Thick smoke from a wildfire fills the air in Scotch Creek, British Columbia, on 20 August. Wildfires released huge quantities of carbon into the atmosphere.

;Canada's emissions reduction plan is insufficient to meet its target to cut emissions by 40% to 45% below the 2005 level by 2030, according to a new a report released by the country's auditor general.

;

;The audit found the government's plan insufficient because key measures needed to meet the 2030 target were delayed or not prioritized, according to a statement from the office of the auditor general on Tuesday.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Trudeau's halt on carbon tax could undo years of his tentpole climate policy;

;
;

;Falling short of the minimum 40% target for 2030 would mean Canada missing its commitment under the United Nations' Paris agreement on climate change.

;

;Canada last year released its first real roadmap to meeting 2030 climate targets, laying out detailed plans and C$9.1bn (US$6.6bn) in new spending to cut planet-warming carbon emissions after years failing to meet its goals.

;

;The audit found that responsibility for reducing emissions was fragmented among multiple federal entities not directly accountable to Canada's environment and climate change minister, making progress and course correction difficult.

;

;Canada has missed every emissions reduction target it has ever set but the prime minister, Justin Trudeau, has repeatedly said fighting climate change is one of his government's top priorities.

;

;The commissioner of the environment and sustainable development, Jerry DeMarco, who drafted the report, said the government could still meet its 2030 target “with drive, focus and leadership”.

;

;The audit found that the plan had potentially strong measures for reducing emissions, such as carbon pricing and regulations, but it also had many weaknesses, “including missing and inconsistent information and unreliable projections that hindered the plan's credibility”.
